    <author>
      <name>Simon Sharwood</name>

    <title type="html">Curiosity find Mars' icecaps suck up its atmosphere</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>34 million observations from two Martian years prove Mars is cold, dry and nasty</h4> <p>NASA boffins have crunched 34 million weather observations collected by the Curiosity rover its two full Martian years trundling about the red planet.…</p> <p><!--#include virtual='/data_centre/_whitepaper_textlinks_top.html' --></p></summary>
  </entry>

    <title type="html">Boffins flip the unflippable: Meet the latest storage extender contender</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>New spintronics material in town – it's <i>anti</i>ferromagnetic</h4> <p>A team of international researchers from the University of Nottingham has found a new material – copper manganese arsenide – which could be the future of computer storage, according to a study published in <i>Science</i>.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>

    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2016/05/12/space_and_business_lecture/"/>
    <title type="html">How to make a fortune in space? Start with one here on Earth…</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Reg lecture shows where scientists AND VCs are boldly going next</h4> <p>We all know the ambition of Silicon Valley’s finest know no bounds - not even gravity. So it’s no surprise that some of the world’s finest business minds are training their brain power and considerable fortunes far beyond our own, rather limited world.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/12/dwarf_planet_embiggened/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-12T09:23:06Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>Lester Haines</name>
      <uri>http://search.theregister.co.uk/?author=Lester%20Haines</uri>
    </author>
    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2016/05/12/dwarf_planet_embiggened/"/>
    <title type="html">Dwarf planet intumesces before astronomers' gaze</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Only Pluto and Eris larger than trans-Neptunian '2007 OR10'</h4> <p>Astronomers have used observations from the <a target="_blank" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/kepler/main/index.html">Kepler space telescope</a> and the <a target="_blank" href="http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/herschel/index.html">Herschel Space Observatory</a> to determine that the trans-Neptunian object "2007 OR10" is bigger than previously thought, and now ranks third in the solar system's dwarf planet size league table, behind Pluto and Eris.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>

    <title type="html">First successful Hyperloop test module hits 100mph in four seconds</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Battle for next-gen transport system hots up</h4> <p>Spectators in the Nevada desert have witnessed the first public test of a Hyperloop test vehicle as it accelerated from zero to over 100 miles per hour in a few seconds before running out of track.…</p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Departs orbiting outpost today bearing return cargo</h4> <p>Crew aboard the International Space Station (ISS) are preparing to wave off the SpaceX Dragon resupply capsule, which will return to Earth later today bearing over 1,600kg of cargo.…</p></summary>

    <title type="html">Archaeologists find oldest ever ground-edge stone axe</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>49,000-year-old blade pushes humanity's history of tooling around back 10,000 years</h4> <p>The world's oldest known ground-edge axe has been discovered in Australia's remote north Kimberley region, pushing back the date of the invention to some 49,000 years.…</p></summary>

  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/10/kepler_space_telescope_bags_massive_haul_of_1284_new_planets/</id>

    <author>
      <name>Iain Thomson</name>

    <title type="html">Kepler space telescope spots 1,284 new planets</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>And nine of them are similar to Earth, says NASA</h4> <p>It's barely been 30 years since NASA spotted its first planet outside our solar system but on Tuesday the agency reported its biggest collection of sightings to date – 1,284 confirmed planets, along with 1,327 additional probable sightings and 707 possibles.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>

    <title type="html">Russia poised to unleash 'Son of Satan' ICBM</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Hello RS-28 Sarmat, goodbye Texas</h4> <p>Russia has announced it's ready to start field trials on its RS-28 Sarmat intercontinental ballistic missile, intended to replace the existing R-36M2 Voevoda (NATO designation SS-18 "Satan").…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/10/tabbys_stars_twinkle_probably_the_boring_business_of_calibration/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-10T05:30:08Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>Richard Chirgwin</name>
      <uri>http://search.theregister.co.uk/?author=Richard%20Chirgwin</uri>
    </author>
    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2016/05/10/tabbys_stars_twinkle_probably_the_boring_business_of_calibration/"/>
    <title type="html">Tabby's Star's twinkle probably the boring business of calibration</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Sorry, people, there is NO Dyson sphere out there</h4> <p>Put the boffins in a cage and break out the popcorn: a new analysis suggests the “long-term decline” in the light observed from the hotly-speculated-upon “Tabby's star” tells us more about calibrating Earth instruments than alien gigastructures.…</p> <p><!--#include virtual='/data_centre/_whitepaper_textlinks_top.html' --></p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/09/mercury_transit/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-09T09:09:12Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>Lester Haines</name>
      <uri>http://search.theregister.co.uk/?author=Lester%20Haines</uri>
    </author>
    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2016/05/09/mercury_transit/"/>
    <title type="html">Sic transit Mercury Monday</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Planet nips across Sun's fiery face today</h4> <p>Mercury will transit the Sun today between 11:12 GMT (7:12 AM EDT, 12:12 BST) and 18:42 GMT (2:42 PM EDT; 19:42 BST), with <a target="_blank" href="http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/nasatv/index.html">NASA TV</a> offering a live feed from its <a target="_blank" href="https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/sdo/main/index.html">Solar Dynamics Observatory</a> (SDO). The space agency has full details on its coverage of the event <a target="_blank" href="http://www.nasa.gov/topics/solarsystem/features/eclipse/index.html">here</a>.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>NASA's latest New Horizons data haul</h4> <p>NASA's latest data release from its New Horizons probe has confirmed the reason that Pluto's moon Hydra is covered by ice.…</p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Take a walk on the hot planet</h4> <p>NASA, the US Geological Survey and various university faculties have released a dream package for the imaginary hiker and geodata geek: a topographical model of Mercury.…</p></summary>

  <entry>

    <title type="html">Watch it again: SpaceX's boomerang rocket lands on robo-sea-barge</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>You're making it look easy, folks</h4> <p><strong>+Pictures</strong>  The remarkable engineering achievement of landing a rocket on a ship was repeated for a second time earlier today – and under more difficult circumstances.…</p></summary>

  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/06/polar_vessel_attenborough/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-06T10:54:11Z</updated>
    <author>

    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2016/05/06/polar_vessel_attenborough/"/>
    <title type="html">Brit polar vessel christened <i>RRS Sir David Attenborough</i></title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Boaty McBoatface not entirely sunk, though</h4> <p>The Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) has <a target="_blank" href="https://twitter.com/NERCscience/status/728502396297609216">announced</a> that its shiny new £200m, 15,000 tonne polar research ship will be named <i>RRS Sir David Attenborough</i>, in honour of the Brit naturalist and broadcaster.…</p> <p><!--#include virtual='/data_centre/_whitepaper_textlinks_top.html' --></p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/06/29_years_of_data_shows_no_mobile_phone_brain_cancer_link/</id>

    <title type="html">29 years of data shows no mobile phone brain cancer link</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Steep increase in phone use produces 'no increase in brain cancer incidence'</h4> <p>An Australian study has found no increase in brain cancers over the last 29 years, despite enormous increase in use of mobile phones.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/05/robot_surgeon_outperforms_human_doctor_with_porcine_patient/</id>

    <title type="html">Robot surgeon outperforms human doctor with porcine patients</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Soft-tissue surgery automation looms</h4> <p>Surgeons beware, your jobs may not have a long-term future after a robot managed to stitch together live soft tissue better than its fleshy counterparts.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/05/nevada_cloudseeding_drone/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-05T01:02:07Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>Iain Thomson</name>
      <uri>http://search.theregister.co.uk/?author=Iain%20Thomson</uri>
    </author>
    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2016/05/05/nevada_cloudseeding_drone/"/>
    <title type="html">Nerds make it rain in Nevada. The Las Vegas strip? No, cloud-seeding drones over the desert</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Big plans ahead if the FAA gets its act together</h4> <p>Cloud seeding – spraying chemicals into the air to encourage rainfall – used to be regarded as a fringe science at best, but now it's kind of a big deal. As such, eggheads in Nevada hope to use drones to turn parts of the largely arid US state, otherwise famous for the Las Vegas adult playground, green.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/04/gravitational_wave_scientists_win_special_breakthrough_prize/</id>

    <title type="html">Space boffins win $3m prize for discovering gravitational waves</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Special Breakthrough Prize for all scientists and engineers working on LIGO</h4> <p>The team of scientists involved in the successful detection of gravitational waves has been awarded the Special Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics – along with $3m.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/04/mercury_transit/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-04T11:19:13Z</updated>

      <name>Lester Haines</name>

    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2016/05/04/mercury_transit/"/>
    <title type="html">Mercury to transit Sun: Viewer discretion advised</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>To avoid blindness, watch live with NASA</h4> <p>Mercury will transit the Sun next Monday, and those wishing to witness this occasional event without risking blindness will be pleased to know that NASA will have <a target="_blank" href="http://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-to-provide-coverage-of-may-9-mercury-transit-of-the-sun">full coverage</a>.…</p> <p><!--#include virtual='/data_centre/_whitepaper_textlinks_top.html' --></p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/04/eta_aquarid_metors/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-04T10:28:05Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>Lester Haines</name>
      <uri>http://search.theregister.co.uk/?author=Lester%20Haines</uri>
    </author>
    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2016/05/04/eta_aquarid_metors/"/>
    <title type="html">Skygazers: Brace yourselves for a kick in the Aquarids</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Meteor shower peak ahoy, cloud and rain a cert</h4> <p>The annual <a target="_blank" href="http://meteorshowersonline.com/eta_aquarids.html">Eta Aquarid meteor display</a> will peak on the night of 5/6 May, with skygazers not suffering the traditional cloud and driving rain advised to keep an eye out for maximum burning dust from Halley's Comet at around 3-5 am on the 6th.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/04/kepler_telescope_hacking/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-04T07:38:04Z</updated>

    <title type="html">Revealed: How NASA saved the Kepler space telescope from suicide</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>And you think you’ve had tough remote support jobs</h4> <p>Waking up to a phone call in the wee small hours of the morning is almost never good. It’s usually a wrong number, a drunk ex wanting to talk, or the news that someone has died.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2016/05/03/endeavour_discovery/</id>
    <updated>2016-05-03T15:54:06Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>Lester Haines</name>
      <uri>http://search.theregister.co.uk/?author=Lester%20Haines</uri>
    </author>

    <title type="html"><i>El Reg</i> Quid-A-Day Nosh Posse spared chickpea ordeal</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>The war on malaria continues, however</h4> <p>Mercifully for the members of the <i>El Reg</i> Quid-A-Day Nosh Posse, who have for the last few years suffered an annual five days of dietary privation as they attempted to subsist on £1 per day for food, the <a target="_blank" href="https://www.livebelowtheline.com/uk/thankyou">Live Below the Line challenge</a> has been suspended until 2017.…</p></summary>
